simplified: Your dreams can give you ideas about things you didn't know you were thinking about. Some common dreams, like flying, falling, losing your teeth, or being naked in public, might have similar meanings for most people. However, to really understand what they mean to you, you need to link them to what's happening in your life and how you're feeling every day.
original: Your dreams might show you all kinds of insights into things that you didn't realise you were thinking about. Common dreams like being able to fly or falling, your teeth falling out or having no clothes on in a public place probably mean something similar in most people. But the key to understanding exactly what they mean to you is to connect them to the events and feelings in your daily life.

simplified: One of the most interesting cases of wild animals living in a city is the wild dogs of Moscow. There are about 35,000 wild dogs living on the streets of Moscow. Some of these dogs were born wild, while others were once pets that people did not want anymore. Some dogs live alone, and others live in groups. In 2010, scientists studied these dogs and found that they have adapted very well to city life. They have learned to cross the street with people, and some dogs even seem to understand traffic lights.
original: One of the most interesting cases of wild animals living in a city are the wild dogs of Moscow. In Moscow, there are approximately 35,000 wild dogs living on the streets. Some of the dogs were born wild, while others are pets that have been abandoned by their owners. Some dogs live alone and others live in packs. In 2010, scientists studied the dogs and found that the dogs have adapted remarkably successfully to urban life. They have learned that it is safer to cross the street with people and some dogs appear to understand traffic lights.

simplified: Wonder is the first book written by RJ Palacio, a writer from New York. She got the idea for the book after seeing a girl with a face that was different from most people's. The book has been very popular in the United States and has won several prizes. Many schools are using it to talk about important issues like bullying, friendship, and what it's like to be different from others. A movie based on the book is being made, and many people, including me, are excited to see what RJ Palacio writes next.
original: Wonder is New Yorker RJ Palacio's first novel. On her website, she explains that the idea for the book came to her after seeing a girl with facial deformities on the street one day. Wonder has been a bestseller in the United States and has already won several awards. Many schools are using it as a starting point for discussions about bullying, friendship and what it's like to be different. A film version is being made, and many, including me, are waiting eagerly to see what RJ Palacio writes next.

simplified: Chloe has two pet rats, Zena and Roxy. She knows that most people don't usually keep rats as pets, and she's had to explain many times that rats are clean animals and can make great pets if you take good care of them. However, she understands why people might not like them at first. Chloe didn't like rats either until her friend Martin showed her his pet rats and she saw how loving and smart they were. When Martin's rats had babies last year, Chloe decided to take two of them as her own pets.
original: Chloe has two pet rats, Zena and Roxy. Chloe knows they're not typical pets and she has lost count of the times she's patiently tried to explain to people that rats aren't dirty and they make fantastic pets if you look after them correctly. But she understands why people react badly. She didn't like rats either until her friend Martin showed her his pet rats and she saw how affectionate and intelligent they were. Last year, when one of Martin's rats had babies, Chloe decided she'd like to have two of them.

simplified: Cape Town can be a dangerous place for baboons. Some baboons have been hurt or killed in car accidents, and others have been shocked by electricity when they played with power lines. Baboons are in danger of disappearing, so to protect them and reduce problems between humans and baboons, the city has hired a team of Baboon Monitors. The monitors' job is to scare baboons away from city areas or catch them and set them free in the countryside. This plan has worked to some extent, but it's difficult to stop baboons from returning to the city when they see it as a place to find easy food.
original: Cape Town can be a dangerous place for baboons. Some have been injured or killed in car accidents and others have been electrocuted as they played with electric cables. Baboons are an endangered species and to save them and minimise conflicts between humans and baboons, the city council has employed a team of Baboon Monitors. The monitors' job is to chase baboons out of urban areas or catch them and release them in the countryside. This policy has had some success, though it is proving hard to stop baboons from coming back to the city once they see it as a source of easy food.

simplified: I work for a big IT company, but its main office is in the US, so I do my job from home using the internet. This is good because I don't waste time travelling to work or talking to colleagues about things that aren't important. I work on individual projects, and I like the freedom that comes with it. It means I can take time off when my kids have school events or when I need to go to the dentist. However, it can be difficult because I don't have set working hours, so I often work late into the evening. Sometimes, I even skip dinner to finish a task, which isn't ideal.
original: I work for a global IT company, but because their headquarters is in the States, I do all my work online from home. That means that I don't waste time commuting or making idle chit-chat with colleagues. I work on a project basis, and this flexibility is very valuable to me because it means that I can easily take some time off when my children need me to go to their school performances or if I need to schedule an appointment with the dentist. The downside is that without clear office hours, I tend to work well into the evening, sometimes skipping dinner to finish a task.

simplified: In the 1990s, graffiti kept going, but there was also a big increase in street art worldwide. Some artists wanted to make people think about important issues like war, inequality, and unfair treatment, so they created art with strong messages. Others just wanted to create beautiful and attractive work. In South America, many street artists went to poor areas and added colour and life to dull city walls, making them more beautiful.
original: In the 1990s, graffiti continued but there was also an explosion in street art around the world. Some artists wanted to make political points and produced art that tried to make people think about war, inequality and discrimination. Other street artists were more concerned with producing beautiful, attractive work. In South America, many street artists went to work in poor areas adding colour, life and beauty to grey, city walls.

simplified: People see many things to buy every day on social media, in magazines, and in shop windows. British people are buying more clothes and shoes than ever before. It's easy to shop online without thinking, and big brands sell very cheap clothes. As a result, people wear these clothes a few times and then throw them away.
original: Social media, magazines and shop windows bombard people daily with things to buy, and British consumers are buying more clothes and shoes than ever before. Online shopping means it is easy for customers to buy without thinking, while major brands offer such cheap clothes that they can be treated like disposable items – worn two or three times and then thrown away.

simplified: Sam squinted at the sun as he watched the car drive up to the Big House, kicking up a cloud of dust. The horses didn't seem to care that their owner, Mr Carter, was visiting for the first time in ten months. They just kicked and swished their tails to keep the flies away. Sam waited patiently. Mr Carter only came out here when he had to, which was okay with Sam. The less he saw of his boss, the safer his job was. As Mr Carter got out of the car, he wiped the sweat from the back of his neck. His shirt was getting wet and sticky, and his skin was already getting red from the June sun. Normally, Mr Carter had a pale skin, like someone who spends most of their time indoors, making money while others do the hard work.
original: Sam squinted against the sun at the distant dust trail raked up by the car on its way up to the Big House. The horses kicked and flicked their tails at flies, not caring about their owner's first visit in ten months. Sam waited. Mr Carter didn't come out here unless he had to, which was just fine by Sam. The more he kept out of his boss's way, the longer he'd have a job. Mr, Carter wiped the sweat from the back of his neck. The damp patches on his shirt drew together like shapes in an atlas. His skin was already turning ruddy in the June sun. Otherwise he had the indoor tan of a man that made money while other people did the work.

simplified: In Berlin, Germany, many people were upset about shooting pigs to control their numbers. There were strong disagreements between hunters and people who care about animals. The city council listened to the complaints and decided to try a more peaceful approach. They put up fences to keep the pigs away and made a rule that it's not allowed to feed them. It's not clear if this will work, but it might be difficult because warmer winters mean there are more pigs than before.
original: Many city residents in Berlin, Germany complained that shooting pigs was unnecessarily cruel and there were heated arguments between hunters and animal lovers. In response to protests, the city council decided to take more peaceful action against pigs. Instead of shooting them, they have put up fences and made it illegal to feed the pigs. Time will tell if this strategy works, though it may be a losing battle as warmer winters mean that pig numbers are greater than in the past.

simplified: Suzanne Collins got an idea for the Hunger Games from Greek mythology. When she was a kid, she loved the story of Theseus and the Minotaur. In this story, the city of Athens is controlled by Crete. The people of Athens don't like being ruled, so they rebel. As punishment, the king of Crete, Minos, makes Athens send seven boys and seven girls to Crete every year. These young people are put into a maze and eaten by a monster called the Minotaur. But one of the young people, Theseus, is brave and kills the Minotaur. Suzanne thinks of Katniss, the main character in the Hunger Games, as a modern version of Theseus.
original: An important inspiration for the Hunger Games book comes from Suzanne's love of classical Greek mythology. When she was a child, one of her favourite stories was Theseus and the Minotaur. In this story the city of Athens is ruled by Crete, but the Athenians rebel. As a punishment, Minos the king of Crete forces the Athenians to send seven boys and seven girls to Crete every year. The youths are thrown into the labyrinth and eaten by a monster that lives there called the Minotaur. But one of the youths, named Theseus, fights the Minotaur and kills it. Suzanne sees Katniss Everdeen as a futuristic Theseus.

simplified: By bringing people and animals together, zoos can teach the public about the importance of protecting animals and their homes. Some zoos give a safe home to animals that have been treated badly in circuses or abandoned as pets. Zoos also do important studies on how animals behave and how to make them healthy again when they are sick.
original: By bringing people and animals together, zoos have the potential to educate the public about conservation issues and inspire people to protect animals and their habitats. Some zoos provide a safe environment for animals which have been mistreated in circuses, or pets which have been abandoned. Zoos also carry out important research into subjects like animal behaviour and how to treat illnesses.

simplified: A new trend is appearing that goes against consumerism - the 'buy nothing' trend. This idea started in Canada in the early 1990s and then spread to the US. It began as a reaction to people spending too much money on Black Friday and Cyber Monday, which are big shopping days during Thanksgiving weekend. On Buy Nothing Day, people organize protests and even cut up their credit cards to show they don't want to spend. Throughout the year, Buy Nothing groups swap and fix things they already have, instead of buying new ones.
original: A different trend is springing up in opposition to consumerism – the 'buy nothing' trend. The idea originated in Canada in the early 1990s and then moved to the US, where it became a rejection of the overspending and overconsumption of Black Friday and Cyber Monday during Thanksgiving weekend. On Buy Nothing Day people organise various types of protests and cut up their credit cards. Throughout the year, Buy Nothing groups organise the exchange and repair of items they already own.

simplified: Is graffiti art or vandalism? It depends on how you see it, but in many countries, writing or painting on public or private property is seen as vandalism. Many street artists have been stopped by the police and some have had to pay fines. Many city councils are unhappy about the high cost of removing graffiti from buildings, buses, and trains.
original: Is graffiti art or vandalism? This depends on your point of view, but in many countries, writing or painting on public or private property is considered vandalism. Many street artists have been stopped by the police and some have had to pay fines. Many city councils complain about the high cost of cleaning graffiti off buildings, buses and trains.

simplified: What does the art world think of graffiti and street art? Lately, more and more people are starting to see it as a real form of art. There have been big exhibitions of street art in galleries in cities like Paris, London, and Los Angeles. In 2008, the American artist Elura Emerald put together a street art show at a gallery in New York. She stood up for street artists, saying 'artists who paint on the street are just expressing themselves and not harming anyone. They deserve to be appreciated and celebrated'.
original: What does the art world think of graffiti and street art? Recently, there has been a growing recognition of its value as an art form. There have been major exhibitions of street art in galleries in Paris, London and Los Angeles. The American artist Elura Emerald organised a street art exhibition at a New York gallery in 2008. She defended street artists, saying 'artists who paint on the street are merely expressing themselves, not hurting anyone. They should be appreciated and celebrated'.

simplified: Most people have four to six dreams every night after they turn ten. This means they can have around 2,000 dreams per year. By the time they are 80 years old, they might have had about 140,000 dreams. Although people forget most of their dreams - 95-99% of them - they still remember a few thousand over their lifetime. It's not surprising that sometimes a dream is followed by a similar event in real life, just by chance. This is especially true if the dream is about something that happens often in daily life.
original: If most people have four to six dreams every night after the age of ten, that's as many as 2,000 dreams per year. So, by the time they reach 80 years old the average person might have had 140,000 dreams. Even if we forget 95–99 per cent of our dreams, that's still a few thousand remembered dreams across a lifetime. It's not too difficult to believe that, by coincidence, a dream event is followed by a real-life event that's similar to it, especially if the subject of the dream is something that happens often in everyday life.

simplified: The Hunger Games is set in the future, after a big disaster that destroyed North America. The new country is called Panem, and it's divided into twelve poor areas, known as districts, which are controlled by a rich and powerful government called the Capitol. The Capitol has complete control over the country. Each district has to produce something specific for the Capitol, like food or materials. For example, District 12, where the story starts, is responsible for providing all the coal that the country needs. A long time ago, there was a thirteenth district, but it tried to fight against the Capitol and was completely destroyed as a result.
original: The Hunger Games takes place in the future, after the destruction of North America. The country is called Panem and is made up of twelve poor districts governed by the wealthy Capitol. The Capitol holds absolute power over the nation. Each district is responsible for producing different things for the Capitol. District 12, where the story begins, provides all the coal for the country. There used to be a thirteenth district but they rebelled against the Capitol in the past and were destroyed.

simplified: Wild animals often enter cities to find food. In Cape Town, South Africa, baboons have begun visiting areas where people live on the edge of the city to eat. They open bins and eat fruit from gardens. Some baboons are even brave enough to go into people's homes and take food from cupboards and fridges. Baboons can be aggressive and have attacked many pets, so it's no surprise that many city residents don't want them around.
original: Often wild animals come into cities to look for food. In Cape Town, South Africa, baboons have started coming into residential areas on the edge of the city to feed. They open rubbish bins and eat fruit from gardens and orchards. Some brave baboons have even come into people's houses and taken food from kitchen cupboards and fridges! Baboons can be aggressive and have attacked a lot of pet animals, so understandably, many city residents don't welcome their presence.

simplified: Many accidents happen when a bridge is being built. These accidents often occur because the engineers make a mistake, such as calculating something incorrectly. As a result, the bridge can collapse under its own weight, which can be fatal for the workers who are on it at that moment.
original: A large number of bridge accidents occur during the construction of the bridge itself. These accidents are often due to an error made by the engineers, such as a miscalculation. The bridge collapses under its own weight, and this can be deadly for the workers on it at the time.

simplified: George Lucas was one of the first film directors to use the 17 stages of the hero's journey in his story. This is a idea that says a hero starts with a normal life, but then something happens that leads them to a big adventure that changes everything. At the start of Star Wars, Luke has a normal life with his aunt and uncle, fixing robots. When he finds a message from Princess Leia to Obi-Wan Kenobi inside the robot R2D2, it is the event that starts Luke's adventure. This event is called 'the call to adventure', which is the beginning of the hero's journey.
original: George Lucas was one of the early film directors to directly base his story on the 17 stages of the hero's journey. Typically the hero starts the story living an ordinary life, but something happens that calls them to an adventure that changes everything. At the beginning of Star Wars, Luke lives an ordinary life with his aunt and uncle, repairing robots. When he finds Princess Leia's message to Obi-Wan Kenobi inside the robot R2D2, it is 'the call to adventure' that starts the hero on his journey.

simplified: Another way to stop a big asteroid from hitting Earth is to use a nuclear bomb to blow it up. This idea might sound like a movie plot, and it was actually the idea behind the 1998 film Armageddon. However, it's a real proposal from NASA, called the Hypervelocity Asteroid Mitigation Mission for Emergency Response, or HAMMER for short. The plan involves firing eight-ton rockets at the approaching asteroid to try and push it off course. If the asteroid is too close to Earth for this to work, the rockets would carry nuclear bombs to destroy it instead.
original: Another suggested defence against a PHA on course to hit Earth is to blow it up using a nuclear weapon. It may sound like a plot from a film, and it was the subject of the 1998 film Armageddon, but the Hypervelocity Asteroid Mitigation Mission for Emergency Response (HAMMER) is a genuine NASA proposal. The eight-ton rockets would be fired at an approaching asteroid with the hope of bumping it off course. If the asteroid was too close to Earth for this plan to work, the rockets would carry nuclear bombs to blow it up instead.

simplified: According to Campbell, the hero first says no to the exciting journey, but then a helpful guide appears and assists them. The hero then decides to 'take the first step' and enter a new and 'special world' where the adventure takes place. The next part involves overcoming difficulties, battling opponents and meeting allies as the hero gets ready to face their greatest challenge. For Luke, the guide is Obi-Wan, the allies are Han Solo and the robots R2D2 and C3PO, and the enemy is Darth Vader in the special world of the Death Star.
original: According to Campbell, the hero at first refuses the call to adventure, but a mentor appears who helps them and they decide to 'cross the threshold' and travel into the 'special world' where the adventure happens. The next stage consists of passing tests, fighting enemies and meeting friends as the hero prepares to face their biggest challenge. For Luke the mentor is, of course, Obi-Wan, the friends are Han Solo and the robots R2D2 and C3PO and the enemy is Darth Vader inside the special world of the Death Star.

simplified: Some things that people do not use much may seem useless, but they can be valuable to others. The internet has made it possible for people to make money by sharing these unused things. Online groups and websites allow people to buy and sell second-hand items easily. This has made it simple for people to share things with each other, and this is called the sharing economy.
original: Underutilised items may seem useless to some, but could be an asset to others. With the advent of the internet, online communities have figured out a way to generate profit from the sharing of those underused assets. Using websites and social media groups that facilitate the buying and selling of second-hand goods, it is now easier than ever for peer-to-peer sharing activities to take place. And this is known as the sharing economy.

simplified: In the 18th and 19th centuries, two main ideas about dreams became well-known. One idea was that the things we see in our dreams mean something about our thoughts and feelings that we are not aware of. A man named Freud thought that if we understand our dreams, we can understand our hidden feelings and the problems they cause. However, another idea was the opposite. It said that dreams are just a mix of random thoughts and images in our brain while it is sorting out memories and events from the day. When we wake up, we try to make sense of these random thoughts and images and create a story out of them.
original: Around the 18th and 19th centuries two main ideas about dreams became popular. One was the idea that the things we see in our dreams represent things hidden from our conscious mind. Freud believed that if we understand what dreams are telling us, we can understand our hidden feelings and the problems they cause. However, the other theory was the opposite. It said that dreams are just a collection of random activity in the brain while it's organising memories and events from the day. When we wake up, we try to make sense of these random images and feelings and put them into some sort of story.

simplified: I work for myself as a freelancer, which is great because I can decide what I do and how I use my time. At first, I worked from home, but I found it hard to focus. There were too many things distracting me: chores to do, wanting another cup of tea, and my family needing my attention. So, I started working from a nearby café, but the internet connection was poor and I drank too much coffee. In the end, I rented a desk in a shared office with five other freelancers. I liked getting ready to go to work in the morning and being able to concentrate in a proper office.
original: I'm a freelancer and work for myself. This is great because I am in control of what I do and how I spend my time. At first, I was working from home, but I found it really hard to concentrate. There were just too many distractions around: housework that needed doing, another cup of tea, my family members wanting my attention for various things. So I started to go to a nearby café to work, but the Wi-Fi connection wasn't ideal and I found myself drinking too much coffee. In the end, I decided to rent a desk in a co-working space with five other freelancers like myself. I liked getting dressed to go to work in the morning and being able to focus in an office environment.

simplified: Whether NASA can find the remaining medium-sized NEOs depends on getting the money to build NEOCam, a 0.5-metre space telescope that uses a type of light called infrared to find asteroids. If they get the money, they can probably reach their goal in ten years. After they find the asteroids, the team that protects the planet will still need to figure out how to stop the most dangerous ones, called PHAs, from hitting the Earth.
original: Whether NASA can find the remaining middle-sized NEOs depends on getting the money to build NEOCam, a 0.5-metre space telescope which would use infrared light to locate asteroids. If it did get the money, it could probably achieve its goal in ten years. Once logged, the planetary defence team would still need to work out how to defend the planet against being hit by the truly worrying asteroids – the PHAs.

simplified: The 'buy nothing' trend is now popular among social media influencers who usually tell people what clothes and make-up to buy. Some famous YouTubers are now telling their followers not to buy anything for a long time, even up to a year. Two friends in Canada tried an experiment where they only bought food for a year. For the first three months, they learned to live without buying things like electronics, clothes, or home items. Then, they stopped using services like getting haircuts, eating out, or buying petrol for their cars. After a year, they had saved $55,000.
original: The 'buy nothing' trend has now reached influencers on social media who usually share posts of clothing and make-up that they recommend for people to buy. Some YouTube stars now encourage their viewers not to buy anything at all for periods as long as a year. Two friends in Canada spent a year working towards buying only food. For the first three months they learned how to live without buying electrical goods, clothes or things for the house. For the next stage, they gave up services, for example haircuts, eating out at restaurants or buying petrol for their cars. In one year, they'd saved $55,000.

simplified: Religion is important to Pi. Although his family is Hindu, he is interested in learning about other religions. He becomes friends with a Christian priest and a Muslim baker. To everyone's surprise, Pi says he wants to be Hindu, Muslim, and Christian at the same time. When his family and teachers ask him to choose just one, Pi says 'I just want to love God'. They are surprised by his answer, but from then on, they let Pi decide for himself what he believes about religion.
original: Religion is important to Pi. Though his family is Hindu, he is curious about other religions and he makes friends with a Christian priest and a Muslim baker. To everyone's surprise, Pi declares himself to be simultaneously Hindu, Muslim and Christian. When his family and teachers ask him to choose just one religion, Pi refuses, saying 'I just want to love God'. From that moment, his family and teachers decide to let him make his own mind up about religion.

simplified: Some people believe that writing down your dreams can help you have lucid dreams. A lucid dream is when you know you're dreaming and can control what happens in the dream. This means you can change a bad dream into a good one, or decide what happens next, like a director of a movie. Instead of just trying to understand your dreams, you can create them. However, it's still a good idea to have some dreams that can help you understand what's going on in your mind, without controlling them. This is because your subconscious, which is the part of your mind that thinks and feels without you realizing it, can tell you things you need to know.
original: Some people think writing your dreams down can open your mind to lucid dreaming. Lucid dreams are dreams where you're not only aware you're dreaming but you can make decisions to affect the events of your dreams. So, maybe you can turn a nightmare into a safe-feeling dream, or you can direct the plot of your dream like a film director. Then, instead of just working out the meaning of your dreams, you'll be creating them, though you might want to continue having some dreams that allow your subconscious to tell you what's on your mind!

simplified: People may not think they are contributing to the problem of disposable clothing because they give their unwanted clothes to charity. However, charity shops cannot sell all the clothes they receive. 'Fast fashion' quickly goes out of style and is often of such poor quality that it cannot be recycled; as a result, people do not want to buy it second-hand. Large amounts of clothing end up being discarded, and many items that charities cannot sell are sent to other countries, leading to additional economic and environmental issues.
original: People might not realise they are part of the disposable clothing problem because they donate their unwanted clothes to charities. But charity shops can't sell all those unwanted clothes. 'Fast fashion' goes out of fashion as quickly as it came in and is often too poor quality to recycle; people don't want to buy it second-hand. Huge quantities end up being thrown away, and a lot of clothes that charities can't sell are sent abroad, causing even more economic and environmental problems.

simplified: Some adventurers today don't stop at just one exciting trip. They keep going from one challenge to the next. Meagan McGrath from Canada is a great example. She has climbed the highest mountain on each continent, cycled across Canada, and run a very long race in the Sahara Desert where it was extremely hot - 45ºC. But maybe her most amazing trip was when she went skiing to the South Pole. On the first day, she had a big accident - she fell into a glacier, which is a big river of ice, and had to be rescued. Most people would have stopped there, but Meagan didn't give up. She kept going and reached the South Pole 40 days later. She had to pull a special sled, called a sledge, with a tent and all her food through very cold weather and icy storms.
original: Not content with one amazing trip, some of today's adventurers go from challenge to challenge. Meagan McGrath from Canada has climbed the highest mountain on each continent, ridden a bike across Canada and run a long-distance race in the Sahara Desert in 45ºC heat. But perhaps her most remarkable journey was a skiing trip to the South Pole. On the first day, she fell into a glacier and had to be rescued. Many of us would have given up at that point, but Meagan decided to carry on. She reached the South Pole forty days later, having pulled a sledge with a tent and all her food behind her through freezing conditions and ice storms.

simplified: Blek le Rat began by painting rats on walls in his hometown, Paris. Now, he tries to make people think about important social problems. He paints pictures of people who are homeless in big cities to encourage people who live there to think about the issue of homelessness.
original: Blek le Rat started out painting rats on the walls of his home city, Paris. Nowadays, he tries to make people think about different social issues and problems. He paints pictures of homeless people in big cities to encourage residents to think about the problem of homelessness.

simplified: In some places, local governments have tried to stop artists from painting graffiti on walls without permission. They have done this by giving them special areas where they can paint and express themselves. For example, in Taiwan, there are special 'graffiti zones' where artists can paint and write on walls without any problems. In São Paulo, Brazil, the city council has even let some graffiti artists paint on the city's metro trains.
original: In some areas, councils have tried to encourage artists not to paint graffiti randomly on walls by allowing them to work in designated areas. Taiwan is one such place and there are 'graffiti zones' where artists are free to paint and write on walls. In São Paulo in Brazil, the city council has even allowed some graffiti artists to paint on the city's subway trains.

simplified: Faith47 is an artist from Cape Town in South Africa. She creates large, colourful paintings of people and animals. She likes to work in different places and her art can be found on streets, in old factories, and on abandoned vehicles. What's interesting about her work is that it's often temporary - it can be washed away by rain or removed by city cleaners. Faith47 likes this because it reminds her that life is always changing, with things ending and new things starting.
original: Faith47 is from Cape Town in South Africa. She paints big, colourful pictures of people and animals and likes to explore different locations. Her work is found on pavements, in empty factories and on abandoned cars. She likes the fact that most street art is temporary and will soon be removed by weather or cleaners from the city council. For her, this reflects how life is full of change with its cycle of endings and new beginnings.

simplified: In her old job, Gabriela was used to a work culture where people respected those in charge and everyone knew their position. In this kind of culture, the leaders made the important decisions and people rarely questioned them. However, her Swedish team was used to a different work culture where employees often worked together with their managers to find answers and make decisions. In this culture, leaders acted like guides who helped their team think independently and expected their team to share their opinions and disagree when necessary.
original: In her previous work environment, Gabriela was used to a high power distance culture where power and authority are respected and everyone has their rightful place. In such a culture, leaders make the big decisions and are not often challenged. Her Swedish team, however, were used to working in a low power distance culture where subordinates often work together with their bosses to find solutions and make decisions. Here, leaders act as coaches or mentors who encourage independent thought and expect to be challenged.

simplified: When Gabriela noticed the cultural differences between her and her team, she decided to talk to them openly about how they felt about her leadership style. Her team was happy to share their thoughts and told her that they were not used to being given orders all the time. They liked having the freedom to make their own decisions and be creative. When Gabriela told them exactly what to do, they felt she didn't trust them to do their jobs properly. They explained that when they tried to suggest changes or question her decisions, she took it personally. However, they helped her understand that this was just their usual way of working, and it wasn't meant to criticize her.
original: When Gabriela became aware of the cultural differences between her and her team, she took the initiative to have an open conversation with them about their feelings about her leadership. Pleased to be asked for their thoughts, Gabriela's team openly expressed that they were not used to being told what to do. They enjoyed having more room for initiative and creative freedom. When she told her team exactly what she needed them to do, they felt that she didn't trust them to do their job well. They realised that Gabriela was taking it personally when they tried to challenge or make changes to her decisions, and were able to explain that it was how they'd always worked.

simplified: Os Gêmeos are twin brothers from São Paulo. They are artists who paint everything from small tags to large, colourful pictures of people on the sides of buildings. Their paintings are often very big, so they need special machines like cranes to help them. In 2007, they even painted the entire outside of a castle in Scotland.
original: Os Gêmeos are identical twin brothers from São Paulo. They paint everything from tags to huge, colourful pictures of people on the sides of buildings. Their work is often so big that they need cranes to help them work. In 2007, they covered the whole of a castle in Scotland with paint.

simplified: People have been drawing and writing on walls for thousands of years. A long time ago, people in Africa and Europe painted pictures of animals and humans on cave walls. You can also find graffiti, which is a type of street art, on old buildings in countries like Greece, Italy, Syria, and Iraq. In a town called Pompeii in ancient Rome, archaeologists discovered many examples of graffiti written in Latin. These writings included messages about religion, politics, love, and even magic spells.
original: People have been painting and writing on walls throughout history. In prehistoric times, people in Africa and Europe used to paint pictures of animals and people in caves. Graffiti has been found on buildings at ancient sites in Greece, Italy, Syria and Iraq. In the Roman town of Pompeii, archaeologists have found numerous examples of graffiti written in Latin. These include religious, political and romantic messages, and even some magic spells!

simplified: Have you ever wanted to climb Mount Everest or walk to the South Pole? If so, you are not the only one. Every year, thousands of people try to climb the highest mountains in the world or walk across continents. In the past, explorers used maps and compasses to find their way. Now, people on adventures use modern technology like GPS, which helps them know where they are, and satellite phones, which allow them to make phone calls from anywhere. Many people who go on these adventures love nature and use their travels to inform people about problems with the environment. Others want to help people who are struggling and raise money for good causes, known as charities.
original: Have you ever dreamt of climbing Mount Everest or walking to the South Pole? If so, you're not alone. Every year, thousands of people try to climb the world's highest mountains or walk across continents. Unlike the explorers of the past who used maps and compasses, today's adventurers travel with modern technology like GPS and satellite phones. Many adventurers are nature lovers who use their travels to help raise awareness about a range of environmental issues, while others are keen to help people in need and raise money for charities.

simplified: The first test is called DART, which stands for Double Asteroid Redirection Test. This test will be done on a small moon that orbits a bigger asteroid called Didymos. The small moon, also known as 'Didymoon', is 150 metres wide and goes around the bigger asteroid, which is 800 metres wide. The plan is for DART to crash into 'Didymoon' and change its path enough that telescopes on Earth can notice the difference.
original: The first is DART – the Double Asteroid Redirection Test. Plans are scheduled to test DART on the moon of an asteroid called Didymos. 'Didymoon' is 150 metres wide, orbiting its 800-metre mother, and hopefully the impact of DART will knock it out of its orbit enough for Earth-based telescopes to pick up.

simplified: The main character of the story is a 16-year-old girl named Katniss Everdeen. She lost her father in a mining accident, so she has to find food for her family. Katniss goes hunting in the woods near her home, District 12, with her friend Gale. She becomes very good at using a bow and arrow. When her younger sister, Prim, is chosen to take part in a dangerous game, Katniss decides to go instead. The other person from District 12 who has to play the game is a boy named Peeta. Katniss starts to have complicated feelings for Peeta, which makes things difficult for her.
original: The heroine of the story, a sixteen year old girl called Katniss Everdeen, has lost her father in a mining accident and has to provide food for her family. She hunts in the woods around District 12 with her friend Gale and becomes very skilful with a bow and arrow. When her younger sister, Prim, is chosen as one of the tributes, Katniss volunteers to go instead. The other tribute from District 12 is a boy named Peeta and Katniss soon finds herself in a complicated relationship with him.

simplified: Writing down your dreams helps you remember more details about them. Think about the people and places in your dreams because they can help you understand what they mean. After a week, you'll be surprised at how much you've written. Then, you can start to see how your dreams are connected to things that happen and how you feel in your everyday life.
original: Writing about your dreams will mean you start to remember more details about the dream, so think about the people and place where the dream happened as they might add to the meaning too. Over the period of a week you'll be surprised how much you've written down. Now you can start connecting your dreams to the events and feelings in your daily life.

simplified: In the past, many bridges were made of wood and easily caught fire. This was especially true for old train bridges. When trains passed over these bridges, sparks were created by the metal wheels and tracks. Sometimes, these sparks would cause the wooden bridge to catch fire and burn completely.
original: Historically, more bridges were made of wood and were much more susceptible to fire. This was particularly true of old-fashioned train bridges, where the spark created by the steel wheels and steel tracks could sometimes cause a bridge to catch fire and burn to the ground.

simplified: It's impossible to predict how street art will change in the future, but some trends are becoming clear. Most street artists are young and work in their own city or area, but now more and more are travelling and creating art in different parts of the world. Some artists are also using the internet to communicate with each other and share pictures of their work. Additionally, the art world is starting to accept street art as a real and valid form of art. Even though we don't know what's next for street art, it's certain that it will continue to exist and be an important part of our culture.
original: It is impossible to know how street art will develop in the future but certain trends are emerging. While most street artists are young people who paint in their city or neighbourhood, more and more street artists are travelling and working around the globe. Other artists are using the internet to talk to each other and share photos of their work. Also, the art world is giving more recognition to street art as a legitimate art form. Although we don't know what will happen to street art in the future, we can be sure that it is here to stay!

simplified: Suzanne Collines has always found news about wars very upsetting. When she was a child, her father was a pilot in the US Air Force and he fought in a war in Vietnam. Her mother tried to shield her from the truth by not telling her what was happening, but Suzanne still saw news reports about the war and knew her dad was involved. This was a very scary experience for her.
original: Suzanne Collines has always found news programmes of wars upsetting. When she was a child, her father was a pilot in the US Air Force and he fought in Vietnam. Her mother tried to protect her by not telling her what was happening in the war, but she still saw news programmes about the war and knew that her dad was there. It was a very frightening experience for her.

simplified: Two big companies, PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC) and Deloitte, did global surveys to learn about people's opinions on work. PwC collected over 40,000 responses from people of different ages about workplace culture, communication, pay, career development, and balancing work and personal life. Deloitte did a separate survey with over 10,000 younger people, born between 1983 and 1993, to understand their thoughts on the challenges and opportunities in the modern work world.
original: In a global survey conducted by PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC), more than 40,000 millennial (born between 1983 and 1993) and non-millennial responses were collected on the topics of workplace culture, communication and working styles, pay structure, career development, work–life balance, etc. In a separate global survey conducted by Deloitte, more than 10,000 millennials participated in a study about their perceptions of the threats and opportunities in the complex world of work.

simplified: Erik Weihenmayer from the United States loves doing exciting outdoor activities. He has ridden a bike across the deserts of Morocco, gone kayaking through the Grand Canyon, and climbed Mount Everest. What's remarkable is that Erik lost his sight at the age of 13, which means he has been blind for most of his life. In addition to his adventures, Erik wants to inspire people with disabilities to be active and healthy. He takes groups of young blind people on climbing trips to show them that they can do challenging things too.
original: Erik Weihenmayer from the United States is a multi-adventurer. He's ridden a bike through the deserts of Morocco, kayaked through the Grand Canyon and climbed Everest. Amazingly, Erik has been blind since the age of 13. Apart from his travels, he tries to encourage people with disabilities to live active lives and takes groups of young blind people on climbing expeditions.

simplified: Websites where people can buy and sell things are giving everyone a chance to make some extra money. For example, busy parents might not have wanted to set up a stall at a local market to sell their kids' old things, but now they can use online selling platforms. They can sell things like baby clothes that have hardly been worn and expensive pushchairs that their kids have grown out of, and get some money back.
original: Democratised online platforms are providing a chance for people to make a quick buck or two. To give an example, busy parents previously might not have bothered with setting up a stall at the local market or car boot sale to sell their children's old equipment, but with online marketplaces, parents are now able to sell on those hardly worn baby clothes that their children have outgrown and the expensive pushchairs and baby equipment they have invested in, so as to put some cash back into their pockets.

simplified: Pi and Richard Parker are in the lifeboat for 227 days. They face many difficulties like hunger, illness, and tiredness. They also go through very bad storms and extremely hot sun in the Pacific Ocean, but they manage to stay alive. Sometimes, Pi finds comfort in the three religions he believes in, but at other times he feels very lonely and sad. After a long time, they finally see the coast of Mexico in the distance, and everything starts to change. It's better if you don't know the ending, so you should read the book to find out what happens to Pi and Richard Parker when they see land.
original: Pi and Richard Parker spend 227 days in the lifeboat. They live through hunger, illness and exhaustion. They endure violent storms and the burning heat of the Pacific sun, but somehow they survive. At times, Pi finds comfort in his three religions, but at other times he is overcome with loneliness and despair. Finally, the Mexican coast appears on the horizon and everything changes. It would be a shame to give away the ending, so you will have to read the book yourself to find out what happens to Pi and Richard Parker once land is in sight.

simplified: Chloe came home from school, made a cup of coffee, and took it to her bedroom. She had homework to do, but she could do it later. She wanted to enjoy the quiet time before her parents came home and the house became noisy with people talking, the TV on, or her dad listening to his favourite jazz music while cooking dinner. She liked this time of day because she could play with her pet rats without any distractions.
original: Chloe arrived home from school, made herself a cup of coffee and took it up to her bedroom. She had some homework to do, but that could wait for later. She wanted to enjoy the quiet hour before her parents arrived home and the house filled up with the evening sounds of chatter, television or her dad listening to his beloved jazz while he cooked dinner. She liked this time of day too because she could play with her pet rats.

simplified: In 2010, a team at NASA that protects the Earth from space objects found and recorded 90 per cent of the asteroids close to our planet that are 1km wide. These 'near-Earth objects', or NEOs, are as big as mountains and are anything that comes within 50 million kilometres of the Earth's path around the sun. NASA thinks there are about 50 more to find, but says that none of the 887 asteroids it already knows about are a big threat to our planet.
original: In 2010, the planetary defence team at NASA had identified and logged 90 per cent of the asteroids near Earth measuring 1km wide. These 'near-Earth objects', or NEOs, are the size of mountains and include anything within 50 million kilometres of Earth's orbit. With an estimated 50 left to log, NASA says none of the 887 it knows about are a significant danger to the planet.

simplified: Auggie has decided to go to school, and now he has to face his first day. Like all children who start at a new school, he feels very nervous. But Auggie's experience is even more difficult because of the way he looks. The other kids don't want to sit next to him, and they stare at him or talk about him when they think he's not listening. Luckily, Auggie makes friends with a boy named Jack, who is in his class, and a girl named Summer, who he talks to during lunch. However, the first day is not the only hard part. Auggie soon realizes that his classmates are afraid to touch him because they think he might have a serious illness, which they call "the plague". As the school year goes on, Auggie has many good and bad experiences. But then, something very shocking and upsetting happens at a school camp, and it completely changes everything.
original: Having decided to go to school, Auggie then has to face his first day. Like every child starting at a new school, he is really anxious. But because of the way he looks, it's an agonising experience. Nobody wants to sit next to him and he notices other kids staring at him or talking about him behind their hands. Fortunately, he makes friends with Jack, a boy in his class, and Summer, a girl he chats with at lunch. But it's not just the first day that's hard. Auggie soon learns that his classmates don't want to touch him for fear of catching 'the plague'. As he goes through the school year, Auggie goes through many intense ups and downs till finally an unexpected and traumatic event at a school camp changes things completely.

simplified: The two men looked towards the north part of the property. It was huge and seemed to go on forever. The fences were so far away that they were hard to see. A teenage boy might get very bored and want to run away, but it would be impossible to escape on foot. Sam looked at the largest horse, which was kicking the ground with its big feet. He wondered if the boy knew how to ride a horse. If the boy was a good rider, he could get into a lot of trouble out here, where there were no people around for miles. But if the boy didn't know how to ride and still wanted to get away from his father, he could get into even more trouble.
original: The two men looked towards the northern end of the property. It stretched as far as the eye could see. Even the fences were barely visible from where they stood. However bored and rebellious a teenage boy might get, it wasn't possible to escape on foot. Sam looked at the biggest of the horses, kicking at the ground with its heavy hooves. Could the boy ride? he wondered. There was a whole load of trouble a good rider could get into out here, miles away from anyone. But maybe there was even more trouble for someone who knew nothing about horses and wanted to get away from his father.

simplified: More than 4,000 climbers, from 13 to 80 years old, have reached the top of Everest. Although climbing high mountains in very cold weather and strong storms is still very risky, the best climbers in the world are now looking for new and exciting challenges. Gerlinde Kaltenbrunner, from Austria, became passionate about mountain climbing when she was a teenager. After finishing school, she worked as a nurse, but she continued to climb mountains in her spare time.
original: Over 4,000 climbers, aged from thirteen to eighty have been to the top of Everest. Though climbing high mountains in freezing conditions and violent storms is still extremely dangerous, the world's best climbers now look for new challenges. Gerlinde Kaltenbrunner from Austria fell in love with mountain climbing as a teenager. When she left school, she worked as a nurse, but kept climbing in her free time.

simplified: After climbing Everest, Gerlinde decided to climb all fourteen of the world's highest mountains, which are over 8,000 metres tall. To make it even harder, Gerlinde climbs without using extra oxygen, which is a big risk. This is because there is not enough oxygen in the air at the top of very high mountains, and this can affect how your brain and body work. Gerlinde uses her fame as a climber to help a charity that supports poor children and children without parents in Nepal.
original: Having climbed Everest, Gerlinde decided to climb all fourteen of the world's 8,000 metre peaks. To increase the challenge, Gerlinde climbs without using oxygen tanks. This is risky as low oxygen levels at the top of high mountains can affect brain and body functioning. Gerlinde uses her fame as a climber to support a charity for poor children and orphans in Nepal.

simplified: If we look around at the things we have bought, we can see that we don't use everything we own. There's the warm coat we thought was fashionable, even though we live in a hot country. There's the old smartphone we stopped using when we got a new one. We might have a car that we only drive at the weekends, or a guest room in our house that's now used for storing things.
original: If we look around us at the things we have purchased at some point in our lives, we would no doubt notice that not everything we own is being put to good use: the thick woollen coat which we thought looked trendy despite the fact that we live in a tropical country, the smartphone that got put away when we bought ourselves the newest model, the car that only gets used at the weekends, or even the guest room in our house that somehow got turned into a storeroom.

simplified: Throughout history, people from different cultures have believed that dreams can predict the future. They thought dreams were messages from gods, giving us information or helping us understand things. Even now, many people remember having a dream about something that later happened in real life, like a place, event, or person they met.
original: Throughout history and across cultures, dreams have been associated with prophecy. People thought dreams were messages from the gods, sent to give us knowledge or insight. Even today, many people can recall a time they dreamed about an event, place or person and then, later, the dream came true in real life.

simplified: Some of the biggest and most expensive transport projects in the world are about building bridges. Bridges are very important because they allow cars, trucks, and trains to cross over water, deep valleys, or other roads. This makes them a key part of civil engineering, which is the design and construction of roads, bridges, and other public works. When bridges collapse, they are closely examined to find out what went wrong.
original: Some of the biggest and most expensive transportation projects in the world have involved building bridges. Bridges are crucial links that carry cars, trucks and trains across bodies of water, mountain gorges or other roads. As a result, they are one of the most important aspects of civil engineering and are subject to intense scrutiny, especially when they collapse.

simplified: Gabriela was getting very frustrated with the problems she was having with her team. After a while, she decided to email her manager in Sweden about the issues. Her manager replied with a simple question: was her team still doing its job, and what did Gabriela think would help her work better with her team members? Gabriela thought her manager's response was not clear and didn't think he was handling the situation well.
original: After weeks of frustration, Gabriela emailed her Swedish manager about the issues she was facing with her team. Her manager simply asked her if she felt her team was still performing, and what she thought would help her better collaborate with her team members. Gabriela found her manager vague and didn't feel as if he was managing the situation satisfactorily.

simplified: Dogs that live in groups have learned that people are more likely to give food to smaller, cuter dogs. So, these dogs are sent to ask for food for the rest of the group. Some dogs have even learned how to use the city's underground train system to move around their area. Scientists are not sure how the dogs know when to get off the train. One idea is that they use their strong sense of smell to recognize the places they like to go. Another idea is that they have learned to recognize the names of train stations that they hear announced. Either way, people who use the trains are now so used to seeing dogs on the trains that they don't really notice them anymore, especially the locals.
original: Dogs that live in packs have learnt that humans are more likely to give food to smaller, cuter dogs so those dogs are sent to beg for food for the whole pack. Some dogs have even learnt to use the city's metro system to get from one part of their territory to another! Scientists are not sure how the dogs know when to get off the train. One idea is that they use their excellent sense of smell and have learnt to recognise the scents of their favourite destinations. Another possibility is that they have learnt to recognise the names of stations they hear in announcements. Either way, metro passengers have now got so used to the sight of dogs on the trains that they travel largely unnoticed by locals.

simplified: Ed Stafford from the UK is the first person to walk along the whole Amazon River. He began at a small stream in the Andes mountains in Peru and ended at the river's end in Brazil, two years and four months later, after walking 6,000 kilometres. The Amazon rainforest has many dangers like poisonous snakes, crocodiles, and jaguars, so Ed was always at risk. Luckily, he stayed alive with only a few thousand bites from mosquitoes and ants.
original: Ed Stafford from the UK is the first person to walk the length of the Amazon River. He started by a small stream in the Andes mountains of Peru and arrived at the river's mouth in Brazil, two years and four months later, having walked 6,000 kilometres. The Amazon rainforest is home to poisonous snakes, crocodiles and jaguars, so Ed was in constant danger. Luckily, he survived with nothing worse than a few thousand mosquito and ant bites.

simplified: In the UK, people spend a lot of money on new clothes - over £1,000 per year. This is about four per cent of what they earn. At first, this might not seem like a big problem, but it hides two bigger issues that affect society and the environment. Firstly, many people use credit cards to buy clothes, which means they are spending money they don't actually have. In fact, the average adult in the UK owes around £670 to credit card companies, which is a significant part of their clothing budget. Secondly, people are buying things they don't really need, and then throwing them away. Every year, the UK gets rid of 300,000 tons of clothes, most of which ends up in landfill sites, which are areas where waste is buried in the ground.
original: In Britain, the average person spends more than £1,000 on new clothes a year, which is around four per cent of their income. That might not sound like much, but that figure hides two far more worrying trends for society and for the environment. First, a lot of that consumer spending is via credit cards. British people currently owe approximately £670 per adult to credit card companies. That's 66 per cent of the average wardrobe budget. Also, not only are people spending money they don't have, they're using it to buy things they don't need. Britain throws away 300,000 tons of clothing a year, most of which goes into landfill sites.

simplified: Ed's walk would not have been possible without technology. He used a radio to ask the people who live in the rainforest for food and permission to cross their land. Many of them came to meet him and helped him through the most difficult parts of the journey. As Ed walked, he wrote a blog about what happened to him every day. He used the fact that the media were interested in his trip to speak out against the destruction of the rainforest and to raise money for charities that help the environment and children in Brazil and Peru.
original: Ed's walk would have been impossible without technology. He used a radio to ask the people of the rainforest for food and permission to cross their land. Many of them came to meet him and helped guide him through the most difficult terrain. As he walked Ed wrote a blog, recording his day-to-day experiences. He used the media interest in his trip to protest about the destruction of the rainforest and raise money for environmental and children's charities in Brazil and Peru.

simplified: Many companies have realised that the sharing economy can be very profitable. They want to make money by using resources that are not being fully used. A popular business model is to create an online platform that connects customers with people who can offer a specific product or service. For example, companies like Airbnb help people rent out their empty rooms or houses to others, making some extra money. Similarly, Uber encourages individuals to use their own cars as taxis in their free time, earning some additional income. These companies act as intermediaries, making it easy for people to connect and do business with each other.
original: Businesses have caught on to the profitability of the sharing economy and are seeking to gain from making use of those underutilised resources. A business model that has rapidly risen in popularity sees companies providing an online platform that puts customers in contact with those who can provide a particular product or service. Companies like Airbnb act as a middleman for people to cash in on their unused rooms and houses and let them out as lucrative accommodation. Another example is Uber, which encourages people to use their own personal cars as taxis to make some extra cash in their free time.

simplified: One of the most important roles of zoos today is to help with breeding programmes, especially for animals that are in danger of disappearing. In their natural homes, some of these rare animals have trouble finding partners to produce babies, and they are also in danger from hunters, losing their homes, and other animals that might hurt them. A good zoo provides a safe place for these animals to live and have babies. When there are fewer and fewer of some wild animals, there is a bigger risk that the ones that are left will be too similar to each other. This can be a problem, but breeding programmes in zoos can help: animals born in zoos can be released back into the wild to increase the variety of genes in the population.
original: One of the most important modern functions of zoos is supporting international breeding programmes, particularly for endangered species. In the wild, some of the rarest species have difficulty in finding mates and breeding, and they might also be threatened by poachers, loss of their habitat and predators. A good zoo will enable these species to live and breed in a secure environment. In addition, as numbers of some wild species drop, there is an increased danger of populations becoming too genetically similar. Breeding programmes provide a safeguard: zoo-bred animals can be released into the wild to increase genetic diversity.

simplified: Both types of accidents are very rare, but boats and trains can cause a bridge to collapse for different reasons. When a train hits a bridge, the speed of the impact can make it fall down. When a boat hits a bridge, its large size and weight can cause the bridge to collapse, even if the boat is moving slowly. To prevent bridge failures, it's best to plan ahead. New technologies can help find weaknesses in the bridge's structure, and safer working conditions and better designs can also reduce the risk of these serious accidents.
original: Both of these kinds of accidents are extremely rare, but boats and trains can cause a bridge to collapse for different reasons. With trains, it's the velocity of the impact that can bring a bridge down. With boats, it's the very large mass they have that can bring about the collapse, even if they are moving very slowly when it occurs. The best way to avoid bridge failures is to plan for them. Modern technologies that can detect structural weakness, safer working environments and better designs can all help to reduce these terrible accidents.

simplified: At first, Pi is very scared of the animals and jumps into the sea. Then he remembers that there are sharks in the water that can eat him, and he realizes he has to get back into the small boat. The animals in the boat start killing and eating each other one by one, until only Pi and the tiger are left. Luckily for Pi, the tiger, whom he names Richard Parker, is sick from the movement of the boat and isn't interested in eating him right away.
original: At first, Pi is terrified of the animals and jumps into the ocean. Then he remembers that there are hungry sharks in the water around him and realises his only option is to climb back into the lifeboat. One by one, the animals in the lifeboat kill and eat each other, till only Pi and the tiger are left. Fortunately for Pi, the tiger, who he names Richard Parker, is seasick and has no immediate interest in eating him.

simplified: When Pi is 16, a new government is elected that his parents don't agree with. They are worried about what will happen next, so they decide to close the zoo and move to Canada. They sell some of the animals to zoos in North America and take the rest with them on a ship to Canada. However, a very bad storm hits the ship, and it sinks. Sadly, Pi's family and the ship's crew all die in the water, but Pi survives and finds himself in a small boat with a few animals: a hyena, a zebra, an orang-utan, and a very large tiger.
original: When Pi is 16, a new government is elected that his parents don't support. Worried about the future, Pi's parents decide to close the zoo and emigrate to Canada. Some of the animals are sold to zoos in North America and the family travel by ship to Canada taking the animals with them. On the way, there is a terrible storm and the ship sinks. Tragically, Pi's family and the ship's sailors all drown, but Pi finds himself in a lifeboat with a hyena, zebra, orang-utan and an enormous tiger.

simplified: The Hunger Games is a very popular book for teenagers and young adults written by the American author Suzanne Collins. Since its release in 2008, it has been translated into 26 languages and sold millions of copies worldwide. In fact, it was the first young adult book to sell over a million digital copies. The book has also been made into a big Hollywood movie, which has been just as successful. On its opening weekend in North America, the film made an impressive $152.5 million.
original: The Hunger Games is a hugely successful book for teenagers and young adults by the American author Suzanne Collins. Since it was published in 2008 it has been translated into 26 different languages and has sold millions of copies around the world. It is also the first book for young readers to sell more than a million electronic copies. The Hunger Games is now a major Hollywood film and is just as successful. It made 152.5 million dollars in its opening weekend in North America alone!

simplified: Dreams might be our mind's way of sorting through the thoughts we have during the day, but in dreams, these thoughts have hidden meanings. When we're awake, we usually think in words, like we're talking to ourselves. However, when we're asleep, the part of our brain that helps us use language doesn't work as much, while the part that deals with feelings becomes more active.
original: Maybe dreams are the result of our mind organising the thoughts we have during the day, but they appear in dreams with symbolic meaning. When we're awake, our thoughts mostly appear in our minds as words, like conversations we have with ourselves. But when we're asleep, the part of our brain that controls language becomes less active while the part that controls emotions becomes more active.

simplified: Having good relationships is a big part of being happy. One study found that most happy people have close relationships with friends and family and they make time for them regularly. It's also important to have at least one person you can talk to about your personal feelings, which is called 'self-disclosure'. This means sharing your thoughts and feelings with someone you trust. You don't need a lot of friends, but you do need someone to have a deep conversation with, as well as other friends to socialize with. Just having friends to do things with or talk about hobbies is not enough. You need to feel a strong connection with someone. Some people need to learn how to listen carefully to others to build stronger relationships.
original: Having good relationships is a big part of being happy. In one study, most happy people were found to have strong ties to friends and family and they made sure they spent time with them regularly. You also need at least one person who you discuss personal feelings with – called 'self-disclosure'. Just one person for a heart-to-heart is enough, together with a network of other relationships. It's not enough to have lots of friends just to do things with or chat to about music or football. That deeper connection is all-important. Some people need to learn how to listen effectively to others in order to develop stronger relationships.

simplified: Psychologist Carol Dweck, who supports the idea of a 'growth mindset', talked about the brain's ability to change and develop new skills and talents that we are not born with. Many people praise others for their natural abilities, saying things like 'You're really good at paying attention to details' or 'You're a natural at organising events'. But research shows that if we praise the way people work and try to solve problems, rather than just their natural abilities, we can help them develop new skills and get even better at things they are already good at. This means praising their effort, their willingness to try new things, and their ability to find solutions to problems.
original: Psychologist and 'growth mindset' proponent Carol Dweck spoke of the plasticity of the brain and our ability to develop skills and talents that we might not have been good at to start with. Many of us tend to focus our praise on the end result and seemingly innate talents, e.g. 'You really have an eye for details' or 'You have a real talent for organising events'. However, research suggests that by focusing on the process of how things are done – praising effort, experimentation and problem-solving strategies – we can encourage the development of new skills and the continued honing of talents.

simplified: The rover regularly checks the air around it, and in 2014 it discovered methane in the air. Methane is a simple but important molecule found in natural gas. One interesting fact about methane is that it only lasts for a few hundred years. This means that something on Mars must be producing more methane to replace what is lost. NASA says that Mars releases large amounts of methane into the air at times. The amount of methane in the air increases and decreases at certain times of the year, similar to how a living thing breathes in and out.
original: The rover analyses the air around it periodically, and in 2014 it found the air contained another of the most basic organic molecules and a key ingredient of natural gas: methane. One of the characteristics of methane is that it only survives a few hundred years. This means that something, somewhere on Mars, is replenishing the supply. According to NASA, Mars emits thousands of tons of methane at a time. The level of methane rises and falls at seasonal intervals in the year, almost as if the planet is breathing it.

simplified: The psychologist Carol Dweck from Stanford University did an experiment with a group of ten-year-old children. She gave them problems that were a bit too difficult for them. Some of the children reacted well to this challenge. They said they enjoyed trying to solve the problems and believed they could get better with practice. Dweck calls this a 'growth mindset', which means they focus on what they can achieve in the future. On the other hand, another group of children felt that their intelligence was being tested and that they had failed. They had a 'fixed mindset', which means they didn't think they could improve. Some of these children even said they might cheat next time, while others looked for someone who did worse than them to feel better about themselves.
original: Early in her career, the psychologist Carol Dweck of Stanford University gave a group of ten-year-olds problems that were slightly too hard for them. One group reacted positively, said they loved challenge and understood that their abilities could be developed. She says they had a 'growth mindset' and are focused on what they can achieve in the future. But another group of children felt that their intelligence was being judged and they had failed. They had a 'fixed mindset' and were unable to imagine improving. Some of these children said they might cheat in the future; others looked for someone who had done worse than them to boost their self-esteem.

simplified: Horror films often use empty places like old hospitals, scary houses or ghost towns. There's something frightening about places where nobody lives. We wonder what it was like when people lived there and why they left. These places are also very quiet, which can be scary. Another reason they're good for horror films is that it's easy to believe you wouldn't have phone signal there, making the situation even more terrifying.
original: Horror films love uninhabited places. This could be an abandoned hospital, a scary empty house or a ghost town. There's something about lonely, empty places. What was it like when people lived there? Why did they leave? Maybe it's also that they are so quiet, which can be very scary too. Of course, abandoned places are also handy for horror film directors in that it's more believable that you will have no phone coverage there either.

simplified: In horror movies, basements are often frightening places. This is where something bad might be hiding or where a very bad person has hidden their dangerous things. Basements are usually dark, damp, and can only be reached by a small set of stairs. Even when there's nothing scary in the basement, it can still feel creepy.
original: No matter what kind of house it is, the basement is a scary place in horror films. That's usually where something is hiding or where the evil psychopath has hidden their tools. Basements are always dark and often damp. You can only reach them by a narrow staircase. And basements are always creepy, even when there isn't anything down there.

simplified: Gary Collins, a policeman who was not working at the time, was watching the London riots on TV. He quickly recognised several people he saw and decided to cut his holiday short to help the police identify them. He spent six months looking at CCTV footage and was able to identify 190 people, often just by looking at their eyes. His help was extremely important for the investigation. The police had a lot of footage to look at - 200,000 hours - but special software that recognises faces was only able to identify one person, making Collins' work even more valuable.
original: Gary Collins, an off-duty policeman, was watching the London riots on TV. He immediately recognised several people and cut his holiday short to help with identification. He ended up spending six months going through the CCTV film and managed to identify 190 people, many from their eyes alone. His help was of decisive importance in the investigation. Even with 200,000 hours of footage, facial recognition software managed to identify just one person.

simplified: I find it really interesting to think about how we can speed up the way humans develop as a species by improving our bodies. Imagine being able to put a computer chip inside our brain! Soon we will be able to do this and it will help us to be better at maths, to see and hear things more clearly, and to remember things more easily. This kind of idea will become more and more normal in the future.
original: Personally, I think it's fascinating to consider how we'll speed up our evolution as a species by augmenting our bodies. Imagine if you could implant a computer inside our brain! Soon we'll be able to do just that and enhance our mathematical ability, audiovisual perception and our memory, and this idea is only going to become more and more commonplace.

simplified: The talk was really interesting and the speaker said some things that were absolutely right. For example, let's look at how parents influence their children. If parents are always checking their social media while doing other things, like cooking dinner or waiting for the traffic light to turn green, how can we expect teenagers not to do the same while doing their homework? The speaker also made a good point about people wanting to be in many places at the same time. This means they keep switching between talking to people in person and talking to people online.
